timeline.message: HDDS-3970. Enabling TestStorageContainerManager with all failures addressed.

timeline.bodyText: Sleep lengths in testCloseContainerCommandOnRestart are being increased.  Why do we need to increase timeout on another test method?
timeline.author: adoroszlai

replies.bodyText: I tested it multiple times on my laptop and tests use to timeout occasionally depending on other applications on my laptop. I kept it long enough that there should be no flakiness in the tests.
replies.author: prashantpogde

timeline.bodyText:
Repeated check (eg. GenericTestUtils.waitFor) should be preferred over fixed length sleep:

allow quicker test execution if possible
explicit condition documents what the test is waiting for
timeline.author: adoroszlai

replies.bodyText: Thanks.  What about the other sleep?
replies.author: adoroszlai

replies.bodyText: I spent some time looking around in the code. Not sure how we can do this cleanly for the other sleep.
replies.author: prashantpogde

replies.bodyText:
Changed this to ->

waiting till the replication manager comes up using GenericTestUtils.waitFor and then
wait some more to give it enough time to process containers
replies.author: prashantpogde

timeline.author: adoroszlai

timeline.bodyText: Please use placeholder in log message instead of + to avoid new code warning (sonar).
timeline.author: adoroszlai

timeline.bodyText: Do you know what other thread changed container state to CLOSING?  Don't we still have a race condition here: in the time window between getState and updateContainerState that other thread could still change state of the container?
timeline.author: adoroszlai

replies.bodyText:
no, I couldn't find the other thread closing the container. one theory could be, We stopped processing the heartbeat from the datanode and if it assumes data node is dead, it could close the container.
Yes there is a race condition still unless it could be done atomically. I changed it to try/catch to avoid any race condition.
replies.author: prashantpogde
